context:
Read the survey, basically they found that the current levels of contamination are not "evenly distributed." Most areas are totally fit for human habitation, though "elevated above that of most natural sites."

The most contaminated area is an old spent fuel warehouse where "exposure for just a few hours would dose a person with as much radiation as is normally absorbed over an entire year."

The average yearly exposure for a person from natural sources is about 700 millirem, so the site maxes out at 200ish millrem per hour. The maximum dose allowed by our government is 5 rem (5000 millirem) per year, which is so low there is no detectable risk, so one could tour the most contaminated parts of the area for over 24 hours without risk.

Interesting study.

context: Fukushima is worse

replies.context: You're right, and the worst part about Fukushima is that unlike Chernobyl, the failure wasn't caused by design and engineering incompetence. Instead, it serves as a reminder that no matter how well-conceived a nuclear plant design may be, nature can cause it to fail.

That's a bit of an oversimplification. The design had numerous flaws, all pointed out years before the disaster. Additionally, massive human errors enabled Fukushima: the plant manager wasn't allowed to flood the reactors - Tepco was trying to salvage the plant for future use. Eventually the manager simply disobeyed and flooded them anyways, but that was too late.

Japanese nuclear plant regulation is exceptionally stringent, and the design flaws only became apparent after the event, or they would have been exposed and corrected. Japan is not some corrupt third-world country where something that would endanger the public could be swept under the table. In essence,  an earthquake followed by a tsunami was not a realistic scenario that anyone could have foreseen. GE engineers certified that plant as operationally sound numerous times. Tepco didn't  flood the reactor because they were legitimately afraid of an explosion and further release of radioactive gas into the atmosphere.

The reactor was deemed to have engineering flaws years before the disaster. Engineers were arguing to stop building reactors like this, shut these ones down and build safer ones. And, yeah, Japan's not a third world country, but it has a lot of corruption at the highest levels. Tepco is one of the worst offenders: they release radioactive water they're supposed to be storing whenever it storms near the reactors, claiming it leaked out, and releasing false data, pretending the leaks are small - only for details to emerge later than massive tons of radioactive water was released.

Tepco refused to flood the chambers because saltwater would irrevocably damage them. The plant manager was practically begging them to let him - thankfully, he went ahead and flooded them regardless, but sadly too late.

After the disaster, the Governor of Tokyo stormed the HQ of Tepco and yelled at the CEO for 3 hours. The company has subsequently been nationalized, removing it from the hands of corrupt investors. So, yeah, it was partially a manmade disaster and Tepco executives bear the blame.

Here are some quotes for you:

"It is a matter of record that in 
2002 TEPCO admitted to falsifying the results of safety tests on reactor one‚Äôs containment vessel. In previous decades, the company had doctored reactor shroud safety records. In 
2003, TEPCO prohibited inspectors from visiting reactors and later acknowledged that it systematically covered-up inspection data that showed cracks in reactors. Following a relatively small earthquake in 
2007, a fire ensued at another nuclear plant, and TEPCO masked the fact that hundreds of gallons of radioactive water leaked out."

and, "Regulatory Failure: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant crisis is exposing the extent to which Japan‚Äôs powerful nuclear industry has been subject to lax oversight, or worse. For starters, the effectiveness of the regulator comes into question in light of TEPCO‚Äôs history of deceit. In assessing governance in the industry, it would be unfair to single out only one company, when the entire industry was not subject to proper oversight.

In 2007, Japan‚Äôs government and power industry were warned that plants like Fukushima Daiichi were not built to withstand major earthquakes. Between 2005 and 2007, atomic power plants in Onagawa, Shika, Kashiwazaki-Kariwa and Kushiwazaki were affected by tremors beyond those which they were built to withstand. Since the 1970s, safety inspectors at the 
U.S. Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) have warned that General Electric reactors, the type employed in Fukushima Daiichi, were vulnerable to explosions and radiation release if a meltdown occurred. Yet to date, no actions had been taken by the Japanese government to modify nuclear plant standards.

Lax oversight of existing regulations is also to blame. In 
2004, five workers were killed at a nuclear plant when superheated steam punctured a pipe. It was later discovered that the pipe had not been inspected in 28 years. In 2007, the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency (NISA) forced companies to reveal unreported safety breaches. Ultimately, seven out of 12 public utilities admitted to falsifying
Impressive response.  Thanks for the info and explanation.

You are quite simply wrong. Fukushima had a melt down due to a lack of coolant. A lack of coolant that was due to a poor placement of the emergency power generators. Had the generators not been taken out by the tsunami the reactors may well have survived.
Tell me then, how do you place generators that are tsunami proof? In a sealed room with a 500 ft snorkel? I‚Äôd like to know
Not in the basement, lol

Most nuclear plants house emergency condensers ABOVE the reactor, with valves that fail OPEN with a loss of power.  This enables a natural pump that doesn't need electricity to operate to cycle out the steam, condense it, and lower the temperature and pressure inside the reactor (good old gravity).  Gravitational recirculation (steam flowing up to condensers, condensed water flowing back down into reactor) inside the reactor keeps it safe until you are able to get auxiliary power to the safety systems that rely on electricity to operate.  

At Fukushima, these emergency condensers were fed by electric pumps, which are usually powered by the emergency diesel generators.  These generators were the ones that were housed in the rooms that flooded and were inoperable.  The decay heat in the reactor (the fission chain reaction was stopped by the control rods) was unchecked, the water reacted with the zirconium in the fuel rod casing and produced Hydrogen, and the hydrogen ignited causing the explosions. 

So no, you cannot make tsunami proof generators if you house them in the lower levels of the plant, but you can utilize passive safety systems that do not rely on those generators to stop an explosion.

Perhaps smaller, naval application style, reactors is a better idea.  Many decades ago, in the aftermath of a hurricane in Hawaii, the US Navy pulled a sub to the pier and powered the island.  Where seismically possible give large to medium-sized cities such a plant to power their electrical needs.  Harden the grid as a whole and shunt excess energy onward to those who need, or simply isolate each city grid fm the next.  In seismically active areas, use Cold War tech of "rumble rooms" to protect the plant fm loss of coolant due to earthquake.

Nuclear energy is clean and efficient when well designed and properly run/managed.  It cannot be done "on the cheap."

Again, the response is typical 20/20 hindsight that' happens because when something horrible happens, there has to be a scapegoat. as someone pointed out, the tsunami took out the generators, which kept the coolant from circulating properly. The Japanese government and other investigative bodies long ago concluded that the Fukushima nuclear accident was caused by the tsunami, and the resulting loss of seawater pumps and all electrical power, not reactor design. GE certified that the generators, reactors and turbines were working properly at the time of the event. This is like looking a 9/11 and blaming the airlines for not putting re enforced cockpit doors in the airplanes.  Tepco was virtually strong armed into making an admission of guilt. No reasonable person would have foreseen an earthquake followed by a tsunami. And that's the problem with nuclear power. There's another unforeseen disaster waiting out there, and when it happens, the scapegoating process will begin all over again.
Nope.

Always remember though to keep that catastrophe in perspective.

Number of people killed by the Tsunami:  20,000
Number of people killed by Radiation leak at Fukashuma:  0
The top 3 execs at Tepco were charged with crimes that led to the deaths of many people. So Japanese prosecutors claim that the reactor meltdown killed people.

The generators that were to provide coolant pumps their power in an emergency were fed by fuel tanks that floated and were damaged during the tsunami.  That was accounted for in the hazard analysis when developing their hazard controls for a flooding event.  

The Soviet system was flawed to the "core".  Their designs, construction, commissioning, operations and maintenance were not robust.  They also didn't share lessons learned from past events and accidents (which there were many) for fear of public or international scrutiny of their nuclear program.  As a result, they didn't learn and adapt to prevent the same or worse accidents.  Google: IAEA Chernobyl Report.
